root.pub-comments: "Austric is supposed to consist of Austro-Viet (Austro-Asiatic) and Austro-Tai (Austronesian), but the two may be genetically unrelated (Benedict 1975)" (Egerod 1991: 207-210).
root.publications: Egerod, Søren. 1991. Far Eastern Languages. In Sydney M. Lamb & E. Douglas Mitchell (eds.), Sprung from Some Common Source, 205-231. Stanford, California: Stanford University Press.

child.publications: Egerod, Søren. 1991. Far Eastern Languages. In Sydney M. Lamb & E. Douglas Mitchell (eds.), Sprung from Some Common Source, 205-231. Stanford, California: Stanford University Press.

child.geography: Geographically widespread, represented from Madagascar (Malagasy) to Malaysia and Indonesia, the Philippines, Taiwan (Formosa), (and Japan?) all the way through Oceania to Hawaii, or almost halfway round the globe.
child.publications: Egerod, Søren. 1991. Far Eastern Languages. In Sydney M. Lamb & E. Douglas Mitchell (eds.), Sprung from Some Common Source, 205-231. Stanford, California: Stanford University Press.

child.pub-comments: Author indicates uncertainty about the inclusion of Japanese, but notes that "Japanese is considered a branch of Austro-Tai by Benedict (1990)" (Egerod 1991:209-210).
child.publications: Egerod, Søren. 1991. Far Eastern Languages. In Sydney M. Lamb & E. Douglas Mitchell (eds.), Sprung from Some Common Source, 205-231. Stanford, California: Stanford University Press.
